title: 113_hr4259
content: The "Electronic Books Opening Opportunity for Knowledge Act of 2014" or the "E-BOOK Act of 2014" aims to address the rising costs of college education, particularly textbooks and supplies, by leveraging new learning technologies to reduce expenses for students and their families. This Act emphasizes the importance of providing all students with access to high-quality education to succeed in the 21st-century economy. The Act aims to reduce college education costs by funding pilot programs in higher education institutions to provide expanded access to digital course materials for undergraduate students. Grants will be provided to institutions for this purpose. The Secretary may award grants to up to 10 institutions of higher education to reduce undergraduate students' cost of attendance by providing access to digital course materials. The amount of funds awarded for each grant will be based on the number of students served, not exceeding $2,000,000. Institutions must submit an application to the Secretary to obtain a grant under this section. The Secretary may award grants to institutions of higher education to reduce students' costs by providing digital course materials. Grants will support pilot programs for making digital materials available to undergraduates in multiple departments. Preference is given to applications serving disadvantaged students. Funds can be used for purchasing equipment and software necessary for the program. The Secretary may award grants to institutions of higher education to reduce students' costs by providing digital course materials. Grants will support pilot programs for making digital materials available to undergraduates in multiple departments. Funds can be used for purchasing and maintaining digital content, hiring staff, building extra storage space, revising curricula, and acquiring other goods or services as needed. Reporting requirements to the Secretary are also included. After receiving a grant, institutions of higher education must report to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the pilot program in reducing student costs, impact on student achievement, grant fund expenditures, and any additional information required by the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary must report to Congress three years after the grant is awarded. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness of grants for pilot programs, including estimates of cost savings for students, best practices, types of digital course materials used, and recommendations for future actions. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as cost of attendance, institution of higher education, digital course materials, and open educational resources. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "mobile computer device" and "disadvantaged student," along with information on funding for competitive grants to institutions of higher education in fiscal years 2015-2017. The Secretary may allocate up to $20,000,000 for competitive grants to higher education institutions under this Act. No grants can be awarded after September 30, 2017.
